Szpiroâ€™s small points conjecture for cyclic covers

Ariyan Javanpeykar and Rafael von KÃ¤nel
Abstract

Let XXX be a smooth, projective and geometrically connected curve of genus at least two, defined over a number field. In 1984, Szpiro conjectured that XXX has a â€œsmall pointâ€. In this paper we prove that if XXX is a cyclic cover of prime degree of the projective line, then XXX has infinitely many â€œsmall pointsâ€. In particular, we establish the first cases of Szpiroâ€™s small points conjecture, including the genus two case and the hyperelliptic case. The proofs use Arakelov theory for arithmetic surfaces and the theory of logarithmic forms.

1 Introduction

Let XXX be a smooth, projective and geometrically connected curve of genus at least two, defined over a number field. In 1984, Szpiro [] conjectured that XXX has a â€œsmall pointâ€, where a â€œsmall pointâ€ is an algebraic point of the curve XXX with â€œheightâ€ bounded from above in a certain way. We refer to Section 2 for a precise formulation of Szpiroâ€™s small points conjecture. Szpiro proved that his conjecture implies an â€œeffective Mordell conjectureâ€. In other words, Szpiroâ€™s remarkable approach shows that to bound the height of all rational points of any curve XXX, it suffices to produce for any curve XXX at least one â€œsmall pointâ€. The small points conjecture was studied in Szpiroâ€™s influential seminars [], see also Szpiroâ€™s articles [].

The results of this paper are as follows. Let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} be the set of curves XXX as above which are cyclic covers of prime degree of the projective line. For example, if XXX has genus two or is hyperelliptic, then Xâˆˆğ’Xğ’X\in\mathcal{C}. Our first result (see Theorem 3.1) gives that any Xâˆˆğ’Xğ’X\in\mathcal{C} has infinitely many â€œsmall pointsâ€. In particular, we establish the first cases of Szpiroâ€™s small points conjecture. Furthermore, we improve Theorem 3.1 for hyperelliptic curves (see Theorem 3.2) and for genus two curves (see Theorem 3.3) in the sense that we produce â€œsmaller pointsâ€ on such curves. To give the reader a more concrete idea of our results we now state a special case of Theorem 3.3. If the curve XXX has genus two and is defined over â„šâ„š{\mathbb{Q}}, then XXX has infinitely many algebraic points xxx that satisfy

We also give in Proposition 3.4 and Proposition 5.3 versions of the above theorems with â€œexponentially smaller pointsâ€. These versions are either conditional on the aâ¢bâ¢cabcabc conjecture, or they depend on lower bounds for Faltingsâ€™ delta invariant which are not known to be effective.

We remark that â€œeffective Siegel or Mordellâ€ applications of our completely explicit results require hyperbolic curves which admit Kodaira-ParÅ¡in type constructions with all fibers in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}. There exists no hyperbolic curve for which Kodairaâ€™s construction (see for example [, p.266]) is of this form and we are not aware of a hyperbolic curve for which ParÅ¡inâ€™s construction (see ParÅ¡in [], or [, p.268]) has all fibers in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}. Therefore our results have at the moment no â€œeffective Siegel or Mordellâ€ applications. However, there is the hope that new and more suitable Kodaira-ParÅ¡in type constructions will be discovered. For example, recently Levin [] gave a new ParÅ¡in type construction for integral points on hyperelliptic curves with all fibers in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}.

The plan of this paper is as follows. In Section 2 we discuss Szpiroâ€™s small points conjecture and its variation which involves the NÃ©ron-Tate height. Finally, in Section 7, we give a proof of Theorem 3.3.

In general, we conducted some effort to obtain constants reasonably close to the best that can be acquired with the present method of proof. However, to simplify the form of our inequalities we freely rounded off several of the numbers in our estimates.
